div.p: This dashboard contain panels created using Splunk's simple XML.
All of the panels in this dashboard (with the exception of this HTML panel) can be created and edited using the Dashboard Editor and corresponding panel editors.
Enable the Dashboard Editors by selecting the Edit: On button. For each panel, select Edit to open the panel editors.
View and edit the simple XML code behind this dashboard by selecting Edit XML.

The Splunk Dashboard Editor and corresponding Panel, Visualization, and Search Editors, allow you to create and edit dashboards and panels without editing a single line of code. You can specify inline or saved searches, display returned data in various charts and other visualizations, and specify drilldown behavior. Read more about the Dashboard editor [here].
To add functionality not available from the Dashboard Editors, edit the simple XML directly using the Splunk XML Editor or an editor of your choice.
In simple XML, the available panels are:

ul.li: table: A tabular listing of search data.
chart: A graphical representation of search data.
event: A raw listing of search event data. Can be used to access custom event renderers.
single: A single value display. Uses all the module options for SingleValue.

div.h2: About the panels in this dashboard

li.p:
HTML panel (Dashboard using simple XML)
The HTML panel displays inline HTML. Specify your content between the <html> tags in the panel code. You can add links to other pages in an app, or link to any other page on the Internet.

Inline and saved searches (High CPU processors)
These two panels illustrate how to specify an inline search and a saved search in a panel. These panels also illustrate table and chart visualizations.

Display single values (Splunk server loge events)
Three panels that show the variety of ways to specify single values.

table.title: High CPU processors (inline search)
table.searchString: index="_internal" source="*metrics.log" group="pipeline" | chart sum(cpu_seconds) over processor | sort -sum(cpu_seconds) | rename sum(cpu_seconds) as "Total CPU Seconds"

chart.title: High CPU processors (saved search)
chart.searchName: Pipeline processors with most processor time

single.title: Splunk server log events
single.searchString: index=_internal source="*splunkd.log" ( log_level=ERROR OR log_level=WARN* OR log_level=FATAL OR log_level=CRITICAL) | stats count as log_events
